channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Globally, Orlando Attack Strikes Now-Familiar Fault Lines
item.media:description: People held an American flag in rainbow colors on Monday in front of the United States Embassy in Warsaw.
item.description: The Orlando massacre resonated across the world not as an American anomaly, but because it felt so universal.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Vote Has European Workers in Britain Unsure of Future
item.media:description: Waiters at Suvlaki in Soho, London. The restaurant has employees from Greece, Italy, Bulgaria and Romania.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: If Britain leaves the European Union, visa rules would have a profound impact on employees in the restaurant, hotel and construction industries.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Mexico City Journal: Haze Returns to Mexico City Where Not Driving Is Hardly an Option
item.media:description: Rush-hour traffic on the Circuito Interior, a freeway in Mexico City.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Officials are focusing on automobile emissions in their battle to improve air quality, but residents point to a sprawling city where a car is necessary.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Canadian Neighborhood Rots in the Shadow of an Unborn Bridge to Detroit
item.media:description: The owner of the Ambassador Bridge, connecting Detroit and Windsor, Ontario, is in a long-running dispute with Canadian officials over who will build a second bridge.
item.media:credit: Johan Hallberg-Campbell for The New York Times
item.description: A long battle between Canadian officials and the owner of the Ambassador Bridge over who will build a second bridge to Detroit has resulted in 100 boarded-up houses in Windsor, Ontario.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Libyan Fund Claims Goldman Sachs Exploited Its Financial Naïveté
item.media:description: An ENI oil platform off the coast of Libya. The country’s sovereign wealth fund is suing Goldman Sachs over the way the proceeds of Libya’s oil sales were invested.
item.description: The Libyan Investment Authority claims in a lawsuit that it lost $1.2 billion after it was misled by the Wall street bank about a series of derivatives transactions.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: Qatar Convicts Dutch Woman Who Reported Rape but Will Let Her Return Home
item.description: The woman was prosecuted on charges of adultery and alcohol consumption and received a one-year suspended sentence.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Exchange Heavy Gunfire Along Border
item.media:description: Afghan border police officers rested on Monday after overnight clashes with Pakistani forces along the border.
item.description: The fighting, which forced the closing of the Torkham crossing, left at least 13 wounded in Pakistan and killed least one Afghan police officer.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Suspect in Shanghai Airport Blast Was Mired in Gambling Debts, Police Say
item.media:description: A demolition expert inspected a package on Sunday at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, after an explosion in Terminal 2.
item.description: Investigators say Zhou Xingbo, a 29-year-old migrant worker from Guizhou Province in southwest China, “indulged in online gambling and lost all his savings.”
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Is Unfit to Testify at Sentencing, Psychologist Says
item.description: A defense psychologist argued that Mr. Pistorius should be hospitalized rather than imprisoned: “His condition is severe.”
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Border Clashes Between Ethiopia and Eritrea Heighten Fears of War
item.media:description: The outskirts of Asmara, the Eritrean capital, in February. Fresh border clashes between Ethiopia and Eritrea and recent talk of another border war have opened a vein of nationalism in Eritrea.
item.description: Reports of fighting and possible deaths — and the lack of solid information — raise fears that Ethiopia and Eritrea are sliding once more into war.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Global Health: Malnutrition and Obesity Coexist in Many Countries, Report Finds
item.media:description: Children alongside their mother’s vegetable stall in Nepal in 2012. The Global Nutrition Report found the country had made progress in fewer stunted children.
item.description: The latest Global Nutrition Report is the third since health ministers worldwide agreed on targets for improving nutrition by 2025.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: A Conversation With: Samuel K. Wasser, a Scientific Detective Tailing Poachers
item.media:description: The zoologist Samuel K. Wasser at the University of Washington.
item.description: A conservation biologist discusses his forensic analysis using DNA to determine the origins of seized elephant ivory.
item.dc:creator: CLAUDIA DREIFUS

item.title: Search Is On for King Henry I, Who May Be Buried Under a Parking Lot
item.media:description: Technicians used ground-penetrating radar at the site of a former abbey in Reading, England, as part of a survey they hope will reveal the burial place of King Henry I.
item.description: Nearly four years after archaeologists discovered King Richard III’s grave under a parking lot, experts are hoping to find the remains of Henry under another one.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Britain’s ‘Brexit’ Debate Inflamed by Worries That Turkey Will Join E.U.
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, has said British women could be at risk of sexual assault by immigrants if Britain votes to remain in the European Union.
item.description: The possibility of Turkish membership, however remote, has injected issues of race, religion and tolerance into campaigns leading up to the June 23 vote on whether to stay in the bloc.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Letter From Europe: France’s Largest Labor Union May Have Overplayed Its Hand
item.media:description: A demonstration in St.-Herblain, France, on Thursday against a proposed labor law.
item.description: As the garbage piles up and commuters crowd onto trains, there are signs that the influence of the General Confederation of Labor could be waning.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Police in China Want Rights Lawyer Prosecuted on Subversion Charge
item.media:description: Zhou Shifeng, a prominent lawyer whose arrest last year formed the focus of a Chinese campaign to discredit and dissolve networks of defense lawyers who challenged the government.
item.description: Zhou Shifeng was arrested last year as part of a campaign against lawyers who were accused of trying to discredit the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Uganda Arrests Dozens of Military Leaders Accused of Plotting Coup
item.description: The government of President Yoweri Museveni suspects the officers of having links to the opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, while critics of the charges see them as an attempt at intimidation.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Was Orlando Shooter Really Acting for ISIS? For ISIS, It’s All the Same
item.media:description: Investigators at the scene of the mass shooting at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., on Sunday.
item.description: The terror group has blurred the line between operations planned and carried out by its core fighters and those carried out by its sympathizers.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At Euro, Fights Keep the Focus Off the Field, a Day After an Alarming Melee
item.media:description: Russia fans appeared to storm en masse into sections filled with England fans after a game Saturday night. On Sunday, Germany and Ukraine fans clashed.
item.description: Clashes on Saturday between Russia and England fans and on Sunday between Germany and Ukraine fans continued a wave of violence at the European Championships in France.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN

item.title: London Journal: A London Subway Experiment: Please Don’t Walk Up the Escalator
item.media:description: The Holborn Station in London at rush hour. To help reduce backups at the bottom of escalators, the station is experimenting with asking riders to stand side by side instead of leaving the left lane open for walking.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Officials seeking to address overcrowding have asked people at one station to stand side by side on escalators, instead of leaving room for walking, which causes backups.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Colombian Hit Man Who Became a YouTube Star
item.media:description: John Jairo Velásquez, right, with a tourist last year near the tomb of Pablo Escobar, the head of the Medellín cocaine cartel, in Medellín, Colombia.
item.description: John Jairo Velásquez, an ex-enforcer for the Medellín drug cartel, has gained 9.5 million views since he began posting about his past misdeeds.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE and SANDRA E. GARCIA

item.title: New Chapter for Classic Paris Bookstore: Books Printed on Demand
item.media:description: “We’re completely revising the chain of book production because we’re a bookseller, a publisher, a printer and also a distributor,” said Alexandre Gaudefroy, Les Puf’s director.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Les Puf, which shut about 10 years ago because of falling profits and soaring rent, has a new location and business model: books printed before customers’ eyes in five minutes.
item.dc:creator: CIARA NUGENT

item.title: Ukraine Shields Gay Rights Parade From Repeat of Violence
item.media:description: Gay rights activists marched through Kiev, Ukraine, on Sunday, guarded by police and security forces. Though threats had been made beforehand, no violence was reported at the event.
item.description: A peaceful march attracting about 2,000 people in Kiev was a striking contrast to what happened last year, when members of far-right organizations attacked the 300 or so participants, injuring dozens.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA

item.title: Explosion Wounds 4 at Airport in Shanghai
item.media:description: Paramilitary officers standing guard at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai after a blast that officials said was set off by a man carrying a homemade explosive.
item.description: The police said the blast, at a check-in counter in one of China’s busiest airports, was set off by a man carrying a homemade explosive.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: China’s Call to Young Men: Your Nation Needs Your Sperm
item.description: With sperm banks facing shortages, a government campaign tries to overcome cultural barriers to donation with appeals to patriotism (and some cash).
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: Could Long-Lost Amber Room Be Stashed in a Nazi Bunker in Poland?
item.media:description: A former German bunker in Mamerki, Poland. Researchers have uncovered evidence of a hidden chamber inside, and think it may contain loot from World War II.
item.description: A museum in the country’s northeast says it has evidence of a hidden chamber inside a compound used by German forces, and that it may contain the treasure lost during World War II.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: What in the World: A Chinese Delicacy Straight From the Swiftlet’s Mouth
item.media:description: A caretaker held a bird’s nest and egg at the Swiftlet Eco Park in Perak, Malaysia, last year. Prized in China for their alleged health benefits, nests made from swiftlets’ saliva are a delicacy.
item.description: Bird’s nest soup, including bird saliva, is supposed to improve the immune system, skin and sex drive. The demand means trouble for the birds themselves.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Orlando and Trump’s America
item.media:description: Investigators outside the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., on Sunday.
item.description: Omar Mateen has set a spark to a time of inflammable anger.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: South Korea’s Misogyny
item.description: It's only on the surface that South Korea has made strides toward equality for women. The reality is bleak.
item.dc:creator: SE-WOONG KOO

item.title: Editorial: The World Could End AIDS if It Tried
item.description: The medicines and know-how are there, but in many countries the money and political will are not.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
